sen.j: お守り（おまもり、御守）とは、願いを象った物である。
sen.e: Omamori (a personal amulet) is an item that symbolizes one's wish.
Omamori (personal amulets) are items that symbolize one's wish.
Omamori (personal amulets) are items that symbolize one's wish.

sen.j: 身に付けたり、特定の場所で保管する事で魔を退けるなどの効力を発揮するとされる。
sen.e: They say it has effects such as driving away evils when you wear it or keep it in a certain place.
They are believed to have effects such as driving away evil when worn or kept in certain places.
They are believed to have effects such as driving away evil when worn or kept in certain places.

sen.j: 招福のお守り（タリスマン）
sen.e: Auspicious omamori (talisman)
Good Luck Omamori
Good Luck Omamori (talisman)
sen.cmt: 「タリスマン」を活かしました。

tit.e: A part of a living matter or its shape
Part of Animals or Animal Shape.
Part of Animals or Animal Shape.

sen.j: ケプリ（フンコロガシ）やウサギの足等の、生き物の力を得るもの。
sen.e: To gain strength of living matters such as Kheper (dung beetle) or rabbit's foot
Those that confer the power of an animal such as those consisting of a scarab (dung beetle) or rabbit's foot.
Those that confer the power of an animal such as those consisting of a scarab (dung beetle) or rabbit's foot.

sen.j: 神仏の姿をしたお守りなどもこのうちに入る。
sen.e: Omamori modeled after Shinto and Buddhist deities also belong to this category.
Omamori modeled after Shinto and Buddhist deities also belong to this category.
Omamori modeled after Shinto and Buddhist deities also belong to this category.

sen.j: 参考：精霊崇拝、トーテミズム
sen.e: Reference: worship of the dead, totemism
Reference: worship of the dead, totemism
Reference: worship of the dead, totemism

sen.j: アメジストを身に着けていると酔わなくなる、などといったパワーストーン等の自然物の性質に人間が引きずられ、良い影響を受けると思われたもの。
sen.e: Natural things such as power stones whose quality is thought to drag people and give good effects to them, such as amethyst that prevents motion sickness when put on.
Natural things such as power stones whose quality is thought to drag people and give good effects to them, such as amethyst that prevents motion sickness when put on.
It is believed that the properties of natural objects such as powerful stones have a good influence on people; for example, wearing amethyst is believed to prevent motion sickness.
sen.cmt: NCを受けて、書き換えました。

sen.j: 参考：精霊崇拝
sen.e: Reference: worship of the dead
Reference: worship of the dead
Reference: worship of the dead

sen.j: 十字架やサンタクロース等の、特定の歴史や物語の象徴となる物は物語中と似たような働きを果たすと考えられた。
sen.e: Things that symbolize certain history or story such as the cross or Santa Claus were thought to have similar effects as they have in the story.
Symbols associated with a certain history or story such as a crucifix or Santa Claus were thought to have effects similar to these stories.
Symbols associated with a certain history or story such as a crucifix or Santa Claus were thought to have effects similar to these stories.

sen.j: 参考：類感呪術
sen.e: Reference: imitative magic
Reference: imitative magic
Reference: imitative magic

sen.j: 退魔のお守り（アムレット）
sen.e: Omamori against evil (amulet)
Omamori to Ward off Evil (Amulets)
Omamori to Ward off Evil (Amulets)

tit.j: 呪術的に力が付与されたもの
tit.e: Items that are given power magically.

sen.j: 魔法陣や梵字などが描かれ、人の手によって力を付与されたもの。
sen.e: Omamori on which magic squares or Sanskrit characters are drawn and that are given power by humans.
Omamori on which incantations or Sanskrit characters are written and are conferred with power by humans.
Omamori on which magic circles or Sanskrit characters are written and are conferred with power by humans.

sen.j: 日本の神社仏閣で授与されているお守りのうち、神仏を表す文字が書かれた神札が入っているものなどがここに含まれる。
sen.e: Among omamori offered in shrines and temples in Japan, those contain talisman on which characters that represent Shinto and Buddhist deities belong to this category.
Among the omamori offered at shrines and temples in Japan, those containing a talisman on which characters that represent Shinto and Buddhist deities have been written belong to this category.
Among the omamori offered at shrines and temples in Japan, those containing a talisman on which characters that represent Shinto and Buddhist deities have been written belong to this category.

sen.j: 護符（ごふ）、呪符、アムレット（腕に付ける札など）。
sen.e: Gofu, jufu (talisman), and amulet (a charm that is put on the arm).
Gofu, jufu (talismans), and amulets (a charm that is put on the arm).
Gofu, jufu (talismans), and amulets (a charm that is put on the arm).

sen.j: 絵馬などもここに含まれる。
sen.e: Ema (a votive horse tablet) etc. also belong in this category.
Ema (votive horse tablets) also belong in this category.
Ema (votive horse tablets) also belong in this category.

sen.j: 魔法陣や梵字とはやや性質が異なるが、第二次世界大戦中に日本で盛んに行われた、千人針もこの一つといえる。
sen.e: Cotton belts with a thousand red stitches that were popular in Japan during World War II can be classified in this category, although slightly different from magic squares and Sanskrit characters..

Cotton belts with a thousand red stitches that were popular in Japan during World War II can be included in this category, although these are slightly different from incantations and Sanskrit characters..

Cotton belts with a thousand red stitches that were popular in Japan during World War II can be included in this category, although these are slightly different from magic circles and Sanskrit characters..

sen.j: 日本のお守りなどのように、主として呪術的な目的で作られたものとは違い、装身具や日常的な道具（ナイフなど）を特別な道具で作ったり、石を埋め込んだり、呪文を書き込んだりして特別な力を持つ、としたものも数多い。
sen.e: Unlike amulets made mainly for witching purposes such as Japanese omamori, there are many accessories and common tools (such as knives) that are thought to have special power because they are made with special tools, stones are embedded in them, or magic words are written on them.

Unlike amulets made mainly for magical purposes such as Japanese omamori, there are many accessories and common tools (such as knives) that are thought to have special power because they have been made using special tools, have stones embedded in them, or have magic words written on them.

Unlike amulets made mainly for magical purposes such as Japanese omamori, there are many accessories and common tools (such as knives) that are thought to have special power because they have been made using special tools, have stones embedded in them, or have magic words written on them.

sen.j: 銀などの金属でできた装身具は特別な力が備わっているとされた。
sen.e: Accessories made of metal such as silver are thought to have special power.
Accessories made of metals such as silver are thought to have special power.
Accessories made of metals such as silver are thought to have special power.

sen.j: 大部分の神社では、長方形のお札が封入されている。
sen.e: In most shrines, rectangular ofuda (charms) are enclosed.
sen.cmt: 用語集ではお札は"Ofuda (paper charm)" となっていましたが、次の文で紙以外の材質に触れているので、単に "charm" としました。
sen.e: The omamori provided by the majority of Shinto shrines have ofuda (charms) enclosed.
The omamori provided by the majority of Shinto shrines have ofuda (charms) enclosed.

sen.j: 材質は、紙・木・布等である。
sen.e: They are made of paper, wood, or cloth, etc.
They are made of materials such as paper, wood or cloth.
They are made of materials such as paper, wood or cloth.

sen.j: 作成は専門の業者に依頼している場合が多いが、伊勢神宮のように神宮内のお札製作部（奉製所）で作成しているところもある。
sen.e: They are often made by special companies, but some shrines including Ise Jingu Shrine make them in their own Ofuda manufacturing department (Hoseijo) in the shrine.
They are often made by special companies, but some shrines including Ise Jingu Shrine make them at their own Ofuda manufacturing department (Hoseijo) within the shrine.
They are often made by special companies, but some shrines including Ise Jingu Shrine make them at their own Ofuda manufacturing department (Hoseijo) within the shrine.

sen.j: それをお祓いし清めて出しているので敢えて中身を開封し“秘所”を見ることも無益であろう。
sen.e: They are exorcised and purified before being offered, so it may be meaningless to venture to open and view the "secret part."
They are exorcised and purified before being offered, so it may be meaningless to venture to open and view the "secret part."
The contents of omamori are exorcised and purified, so opening them to discover their "secrets" may negate their effectiveness.
sen.cmt: NCのコメントを受けて書き換えました。

sen.j: 本来は地方の守護・地頭の出した書面や許可証であった物が、文字の読めない当時の民衆にとっては不思議な意味を持つ物となり、現在に至る。
sen.e: Originally, they were documents or licenses issued by local Shugo and Jito (military governor and estate steward), but they were thought to carry a mysterious meaning by common people at that time who could not read, which continues to the present.

They were originally documents or licenses issued by local shugo and jito (military governors and manor stewards), but they were thought to have a mysterious meaning by the common people of the time who could not read or write, and this meaning has remained until today.

They were originally documents or licenses issued by local shugo and jito (military governors and manor stewards), but they were thought to have a mysterious meaning by the common people of the time who could not read or write, and this meaning has remained until today.
